title: England's ghosts of the past banished as dust settled on finest World Cup victory for a generation
text:
As the dust was still settling on their finest World Cup victory for a generation, England’s players savoured a triumph which proved they had banished their demons.

Under the roof of the Oita Stadium in Saturday’s absorbing quarter-final, Eddie Jones’ national team proved that they have added crisis management to their repertoire.

This time, unlike the Calcutta Cup meltdown against Scotland earlier this year, when the pressure came on, they didn’t panic. This time, there was unity and composure. This time, they held the line and rallied. They didn’t unravel.

England's quarter-final victory against Australia proved they had banished their demons

It was a success founded on mental resilience, defensive commitment and all manner of earthy qualities.

England ended up putting 40 points on the Wallabies, but their victory came down to so many nuts-and-bolts factors. It came down to Tom Curry’s relentless dynamism and ferocity. It came down to Sam Underhill’s 20 sledgehammer tackles and Kyle Sinckler overcoming adversity and wind-up tactics to score his first Test try and produce the steal of his life.

The ghosts of the collapse against Scotland were chased out of town. Back in March, a Calcutta Cup procession turned into a calamity as England went from 31-0 up to a 38-31 deficit at Twickenham, before a George Ford try rescued a draw.

Jones admitted that the Six Nations finale exposed glaring flaws which had to be addressed. He brought in sports psychologists. Their input has evidently had the desired effect.

So this time, when Australia surged to within a point after half-time, England’s nerve held and they regained the initiative, on the way to a seventh successive defeat of the Wallabies and a first World Cup semi-final since 2007.

Eddie Jones had enlisted the help of sports psychologists after England's Six Nations collapse

Asked about the ability to stay level-headed in the face of a fightback, hooker Jamie George said: ‘It’s something we’ve been working on for a long time.

‘It pains me to say it, but you rewind to that Scotland game at Twickenham. When games get close, we’ve been criticised in the past; after that Wales game away, too (a 21-13 Six Nations defeat).

‘The most impressive thing for me is how we’ve revolutionised that. We have been able to talk about it. We’ve been in different scenarios and we’ve been challenged a lot in the warm-up games. I feel like, in terms of the mind-set and mentality side of things when games get tough, we look like a completely different team from the one that drew to Scotland and lost to Wales in the Six Nations.’

Scrum-half Ben Youngs echoed those sentiments, adding: ‘What I am most pleased about is the fact that the game got tight, they put us under pressure and everything that we rehearsed and practised and sat in meetings about how we handle it and how we get a grip on it, we were able to do.’

Tom Curry's all-action performance made him a worthy man of the match against the Wallabies

England’s defensive effort was led by the rookie flankers. The vaunted Australian pairing known as ‘Pooper’ — David Pocock and captain Michael Hooper — were utterly eclipsed by the English tyros. Curry is just 21 and was magnificent. His all-action performance made him a worthy man of the match. Underhill was a prime contender for that award too and the back-row alliance continues to galvanise England.

Off the field, team-mates mock the two quirky characters. But when it comes to game-time, they are in awe of their work. Youngs said: ‘I had lunch with Curry today. I said, “How are you feeling?”. He said, “I am excited. I am playing against someone I idolised”. I said, “You’ll be fine, you can show him how the new breed are”.

‘I thought he was phenomenal. So was Sam. What a fantastic day for those two to test themselves against David and Hooper, who are tremendous players, and come out on top.’

England skipper Owen Farrell rediscovered his authority as a playmaker after Jones' advice

It was an impressive occasion for the captain. Farrell was off-colour in England’s last game. After switching him back to fly-half, Jones revealed that he urged his skipper to focus more on his own game. The advice was heeded. Farrell rediscovered his authority as a playmaker and was on target with all eight shots at goal.

‘I am not surprised, because that is just how he is and who he is,’ said Youngs. ‘I even thought the other week when he missed a load, “That’s alright because he’ll bang them all over next week”. He conducted the team unbelievably well and as for the kicking, he loves that pressure really.’

He wasn’t alone. It was a great job all round. England faced their first serious problem of this campaign and they solved it. They didn’t panic. They proved that the demons have been banished.

Their reward is a step closer to immortality.
